VICE Newshttps://news.vice.com/en_usRSS feed for https://news.vice.comenSat, 17 Feb 2018 14:11:51 +0000<![CDATA[More than half of schools have no idea what to do when an active shooter walks in]]>https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/ywqb3x/more-than-half-of-schools-have-no-idea-what-to-do-when-an-active-shooter-walks-inSat, 17 Feb 2018 14:11:51 +0000Every Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School teacher had spoken to every single class about what to do in a school shooting.

âThey knew what to do and we knew what to do,â Melissa Falkowski, a teacher at the Parkland, Florida school, told MSNBC the night of the shooting. âI donât think we could have been more prepared than we were today.â

But it wasnât enough: On Wednesday, a gunman shot and killed 17 people in Stoneman Douglasâ hallways and classrooms. Falkowski ending up saving the lives of 19 of her students by barricading inside her classroom closet.

In the 19 years since two teenagers gunned down 13 people in a Columbine, Colorado, high school, more and more schools have sought to train kids for the possibility of a shooter one day walking into their building. The federal government has even issued national guidance on how to handle a school shooter, instructing officials to teach kids some variation of âRun, Hide, Fightâ â which instructs people caught in an active-shooter situation to try to get away from a gunman and, if necessary, confront him.

READ: The Army is using videogame technology to simulate school shootings

But even as the frequency of school shootings skyrockets, far too many schools still remain unprepared, experts say, and disagreements still linger over whether to teach kids to fight back.

A March 2016 Government Accountability Office survey found that out of 51 state educational agencies, 40 require individual schools to conduct exercises, like drills, to prepare students for emergencies. But only 12 states explicitly require that schools run exercises that prepare students for active shooter situations.

âMore than half of [schools] are not adequately prepared,â said John Curnutt, assistant director of the Advanced Law Enforcement Rapid Response Training (ALERRT) Center at Texas State University, which uses federal grants to train people about how to handle active shooter situations and is recommended by the FBI. âThey definitely have an emergency plan in a big three-ring binder somewhere on the campusâ¦ But as a culture in the school, thereâs very few of them that are really ready.â

READ: All the times Nikolas Cruz was reported to authorities before the shooting

Experts say that kids need more than the occasional drill on how to evacuate a school or lock down a classroom. (In a school lockdown, teachers and students typically hole up in their classrooms in silence, with the lights off.) Instead, they say schools need to hold frequent, frank training and conversations.

âHow often do you practice this type of situation? How often do schools take the time to have drills on safety procedures?â asked Mac Hardy, director of operations for National Association of School Resource Officers, which oversees sown law enforcement officers who work in schools. âThe conversation should be consistent with staff and personnelâ¦ I mean, monthly, at teacher workshops, [at] teacher meetings â because they have those once a week â and these conversations should be as short as 10 minutes.â

An estimated 67 percent of schools held at least one exercise to teach kids how to handle an active shooter between 2012 and 2015, according to the Government Accountability Office report. And if that number sounds high, it pales in comparison to the 97 percent of schools that held at least one fire drill â despite the fact that fatalities due to fires are much less common. While five people died in school fires between 2011 and 2013, that same time period saw 166 people die in school shootings, according to a FBI and Justice Department report.

The office surveyed school officials about this disparity, and found that some worried running active shooter exercises could cause anxiety, including among parents. âOfficials from one of these districts noted the difficulty of striking a balance between providing knowledge and inciting fear, particularly at schools with younger children,â the report found.

âThere [are] people that choose to be in denial, that they will play the odds,â Curnutt said. âThey will not take any special precautions, or take any extra effort, because that [takes] time and money and most school districts are already strapped for time and money and their staffâs attention span.â

Schools may also disagree about what to actually tell children to do in active shooter situations. Jeff Zisner, who trains schools on how to handle such scenarios as president of AEGIS Securities & Investigations, says most experts offer the same advice: âIf you can create distance and barriers between you and the bad guy, do it,â he said. âAnd if you canât, lockdown shelter in place, inform law enforcement, and prepare to fight back if you have to.â

READ: How Florida students changed the way we experience school shootings

Zisner acknowledges that these instructions can become âexponentially more difficultâ to follow when dealing with children, but stresses that if high school students are willing and able to fight, teachers shouldnât necessarily stop them.

âThese are real circumstances with real ramifications, and your job is to do the best you can given your experience and knowledge,â he explained.

But federal agencies still appear to differ in their interpretation of âRun, Hide, Fight.â A 2013 guide issued by the Department of Justice, FBI, Department of Homeland Security, FEMA, and the Department of Health and Human suggests that adults consider confronting a shooter as a last resort. These agencies purposefully refrained from directing children to fight, a Department of Education official told VICE News.

In contrast, the FBI does not officially take a position on children fighting, according to the Government Accountability Office report, and believes the guide was designed to âallow each community to determine whether to discuss with high school students the option of fighting.â

These differences may seem miniscule. However, in a terrifying, overwhelming situation where people may only have minutes to make a choice, they could mean the difference between life and death. The lack of clarity may also decrease the nationâs overall preparedness.

âNot all relevant agencies and officials are included in collaborative efforts or are aware of related efforts and resources,â the report notes, âand agencies are offering different interpretations of the same federal guidance â all of which risks wasting limited federal resources on duplicative, overlapping, or fragmented efforts.â

Ultimately, Falkowski believes no amount of preparation could have saved the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School from the carnage.

âAnd even still, even with that, we still have 17 casualties, 17 people that arenât going to return to their families. And to me, thatâs totally unacceptable,â said Falkowski, as she choked back tears on national television. âFrom my personal viewpoint, itâs time for Congress, government, somebody, to do something. And itâs time to talk about what the problem is, and try to fix it.â

Cover image: "Victims" are led out as members of the Fountain Police Department take part in an Active Shooter Response Training exercise at Fountain Middle School on June 9, 2017, in Fountain, Colorado. (Dougal Brownlie/The Gazette via AP)

]]>ywqw8jSheila KumarVICE NewsCultureArtificial IntelligenceTechnologyArtCreativitycriticjerry Saltz<![CDATA[Trump juggled two sex scandals and a budget this week]]>https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/a3475a/trump-juggled-two-sex-scandals-and-a-budget-this-weekSat, 17 Feb 2018 13:00:00 +0000 h3 { margin-top: 0; padding-top: 15px !important; padding-bottom: 20px !important; background-color: gold; font-size: 1.75em !important; border-top: 1px solid black; } .date { display: block; font-size: 20px; padding-top: 15px; } .hilite { background-color: gold; padding: 0.125em 0.5em; font-size: 1.25em; } @media (min-width: 1024px) { .date { font-size: 24px; } h3 { font-size: 2.75em !important } h4 { text-transform: none !important; }

Like most weeks, Trump kept his communications staff and lawyers busy.

As the fallout from abuse allegations against Rob Porter â formerly one of Trump's closest aides â continued to rain down, the White House also had to reckon with another alleged affair, this time with a Playboy model in 2006. That's the same year Trump was allegedly having trysts at Trump hotels with former porn star Stormy Daniels.

Meanwhile, Trump released a budget, which included $200 billion for his long-awaited infrastructure plan.

It was a busy week, to say the least.

"Best Wishes, Rob"Day 384 â Feb. 9

  • Trump sent his best wishes to his former staff secretary, Rob Porter, who resigned, or was maybe fired, after his two ex-wivesâ accusations of abuse came to light.
  • In the middle of the night, Republican Sen. Rand Paul delayed a vote that forced the government to shut down. By 8:30 a.m. D.C. time, however, Trump tweeted that he had signed a spending bill and that âour Military will now be stronger than ever before.â Also, âJOBS, JOBS, JOBS.â Read whatâs in the bill here.
  • Trump officially blocked a memo written by Democrats intended to counteract a Republican-written memo that he released last week about the FBIâs supposed bias in the Russia probe.

    Not #MeTooDay 385 â Feb. 10

  • Accused by numerous women of sexual assault and rape, the president came down firmly on the âwitch huntâ side of the #MeToo debate, as the Rob Porter scandal unfolded. âThere is no recovery for someone falsely accused - life and career are gone,â Trump tweeted. âIs there no such thing any longer as Due Process?â

  • Trump sent his $4.4 trillion budget proposal to Congress, which would put up big money for two of his favorite things: the military and a border wall. The proposal also contains cuts to food stamps that would, in effect, regulate poor peopleâs diets with âBlue Apron-typeâ boxes of food, as Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney branded it.
  • Trump also unveiled his long-awaited infrastructure plan, which takes up $200 billion of the proposed budget but claims to generate $1.5 trillion. Read about the plan here.
  • After repeatedly claiming former porn star Stormy Daniels didnât receive any hush money after her alleged affair with Trump, the presidentâs longtime personal lawyer Michael Cohen admitted to paying her $130,000 out of his own pocket â which the Trump Organization and campaign hasnât reimbursed. Danielsâ manager later said Cohenâs disclosure now allows the star to tell her side of the story.

"Shut the fuck up"Day 389 â Feb. 14

  • Some students at Marjory Douglas Stoneman High School in Florida didnât want to hear the âprayers and condolencesâ Trump offered in a tweet after a shooter killed 17 people and injured 19 others earlier in the day. âUnless you are going to do something about gun control so no one else experiences what my school has, shut the fuck up,â one person tweeted back at the president. Read what other students tweeted at him here.
  • A full week after Rob Porterâs resignation, Trump finally stopped dodging the question and condemned the act of domestic violence. âIâm totally opposed to domestic violence,â the president said.
  • Meanwhile, the White House is still finger-pointing over Porter never having security clearance during a year as one of Trumpâs closest aides.

Guns? What guns?Day 390 â Feb. 15

  • After the shooting, Trump addressed the nation â and never once mentioned the word âgunsâ. His speech, instead, focused on the GOPâs go-to talking point after shooting: the gunmanâs mental health.
  • Earlier in the day, Trump tweeted his thoughts on preventing mass shootings. âMust always report such instances to authorities, again and again!â (The alleged shooter was reported to the FBI twice within the last five months ago and had dozens of interactions with local police.)

Headed to FloridaDay 391 â Feb. 16

  • Trump confirmed he would leave for Florida to meet with survivors of the shooting, after making a vague announcement about visiting the previous day.
  • The president had to deal with yet another sex scandal. Trump had a nine-month affair with a Playboy model in 2006 â starting three months after the birth of son Barron â according to a report in The New Yorker. Read the 10 most jaw-dropping claims from the report here .
]]>a3475aRex SantusChristina SterbenzBudgetinfrastructureThis week in Trump's Americastormy danielsPlayboy model<![CDATA[How the Mueller team turned social media breadcrumbs into a wide-ranging conspiracy]]>https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/gy8j4y/how-the-mueller-team-turned-social-media-breadcrumbs-into-a-wide-ranging-conspiracySat, 17 Feb 2018 10:00:00 +0000 After months of breadcrumbs from Congressional investigators and Silicon Valley platforms, Special Counsel Bob Mueller finally laid out the U.S. governmentâs case for what Russian agents actually did to influence the 2016 election online.

The latest indictment of 13 Russian hackers includes choice excerpts from the trove of data that Facebook, Google, and Twitter handed over to Congress last fall, synthesized with other material to piece together the Russian government operation that began in 2014 and continued through the 2016 election.

Hereâs whatâs old

Beyond the names of the hackers themselves, the indictment doesnât contain a significant amount of new information. Social media ads paid for by Russian agents were previously revealed by House Intelligence Committee Democrats during early November Capitol Hill hearings with Google, Facebook, and Twitter, and multiple outlets have connected Russian agents to political events and Twitter profiles created by Russians.

One such Facebook ad released by Congress that Mueller included in his indictment was from the page âArmy of Jesusâ called Hillary âsatanâ and urged viewers to support Donald Trump. The 136,000 follower-strong Twitter account @TEN_GOP, which the indictment also references, was fingered as a Russian plant by journalists last October. And events organized by Russian operatives on Facebook have been reported on extensively, as well.

Hereâs whatâs new

But what Mueller does present as new is the actual conspiracy, titled âProject Lakhta,â that set all this digital skullduggery in motion.

The defendants allegedly obtained the Social Security numbers and other personally identifying information of actual Americans. Using those details, and inventing other personas, the Russians then opened bank and Paypal accounts with the assistance of a Californian named Richard Pinedo, who pleaded guilty on Friday to assisting the alleged conspiracy. Those accounts, in turn, were then used to bankroll the ads and other shenanigans, including an event where one person who dress up as Hillary Clinton in a prison uniform.

Other hijinks included simultaneously holding a pro-Trump rally (âshow your support for President-Elect Donald Trumpâ) and an anti-Trump rally (âTrump is NOT my presidentâ) in November 2016 in New York.

When the FBI caught onto what the Russians were up to last September, according to the indictment, one of the defendants said in an email to her family that âwe had a slight crisis at workâ as the FBI âbusted our activity (not a joke). So, I got preoccupied with covering tracks together with colleagues.â

What about the collusion?

Itâs not entirely clear where the Mueller investigation goes from here, but the special counselâs team is already signaling that its work is certainly not over. The Friday indictments do not preclude the possibility of charges of Trump campaign collusion with the Russian government, according to Bloomberg.

]]>gy8j4yNoah KulwinVICE NewsRobert MuellerRussia indictmentsspecial counsel investigation<![CDATA[White House announces new security clearance protocol that could affect Jared Kushner]]>https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/ywqbyk/white-house-announces-new-protocol-for-security-clearances-that-could-affect-jared-kushnerSat, 17 Feb 2018 02:22:05 +0000Chief of Staff John Kelly approved an overhaul to the White House security clearance review process Friday, amid controversy over how the White House handled allegations of domestic abuse against top aide Rob Porter.

The five-page memo was sent to White House counsel Don McGahn, national security adviser H.R. McMaster and deputy chief of staff Joseph Hagin, according to USA Today,

âThe American people deserve a White House staff that meets the highest standards and that has.been carefully vetted especially those who work closely with the President or handle sensitive national security information,â Kelly said. âWe should and in the future, must do better.â

Kelly said that individuals with interim clearances pending since June would be revoked on Feb. 23. It is unclear how this mandate will affect high-profile staffers like Jared Kushner, who is working on an interim clearance and is not expected to be granted full clearance in the near future.

Kelly also said that interim clearances handed out in the future will last a maximum of 180 days, and only if the FBI hasnât uncovered "significant derogatory information." He added any derogatory information discovered should be reported in 48 hours.

Kelly said that he had reduced the number of clearances in the White House and in some cases, demoted others.

âNow is the time to take a hard look at the way the White House processes clearance requests,â Kelly said.

Kelly came under fire in recent weeks for how the White House handled allegations that top aide Rob Porter domestically abused his ex-wives. Controversy swirled over when the administration knew, and why Porter, who resigned last week, continued to be staff security, a position that allows close access to the president. The same week, another staffer was fired because he had smoked marijuana in 2013, preventing him from obtaining full clearance.

]]>ywqbykAlexa LiautaudVICE NewsJohn Kellysecurity clearancesecurity clearancesrob porterChief of Staff<![CDATA[Parkland school shooter honed skills on a team supported by the NRA]]>https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/437njm/parkland-school-shooter-honed-skills-on-a-team-supported-by-the-nraFri, 16 Feb 2018 23:33:49 +0000 Classmates of the 19-year-old who used an assault rifle to kill 17 students at a Florida high school on Wednesday say Nikolas Cruz couldnât stop talking about guns â an interest he was able to hone in part directly thanks to the National Rifle Association.

The NRA Foundation, the gun lobbyâs charitable arm, gave more than $10,000 worth of assistance to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High Schoolâs rifle marksmanship team in 2016, the Associated Press reported Friday. Cruz, who was a member of the team, reportedly excelled despite ongoing violent outbursts that saw him expelled from the school for âdisciplinary reasonsâ in early 2017.

âHe was a very good shot,â Aaron Diener, a former teammate, told the AP. âHe had an AR-15 he talked about, and pistols.â

The NRA did not respond to a request for comment, and it has not issued any statements in reference to the shooting. Dana Loesch, an NRA spokesperson featured in a number of controversial ads for the organization, called the shooting âheinousâ in a tweet on Wednesday.

In 2016, Cruz and Diener were both members of a four-person U.S. Army Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps rifle team, where students trained in marksmanship after school and competed in shooting contests with air rifles.

The support, disclosed in 2016 tax forms, came in the form of non-cash assistance to the club. It was not disclosed what it was specifically used for, though the schoolâs JROTC program did possess Kevlar curtains, which students were able to use for protection during the shooting Wednesday. At least four other high schools in Broward County, where Stoneman is located, also received NRA donations.

The ROTC and the Broward County school district did not respond to a request for comment.

The NRA Foundation has given more than $335 million in grants since 1990 to schools, gun clubs, Boy Scout troops, and churches. Florida got the most donations of any state in 2016.

]]>437njmJosh MarcusVICE NewsNRAMarjory Stoneman Douglasrotcparkland shooterstoneman shooternra stoneman shooter<![CDATA["Scheduleâ prevents Donald and Melania from traveling together hours after Playboy story]]>https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/pam3j8/schedule-prevents-donald-and-melania-from-traveling-together-hours-after-playboy-storyFri, 16 Feb 2018 23:00:32 +0000 The forecast calls for sunny skies and 80-degree temperatures, but it looks like thereâs going to be a cold front passing through Mar-a-Lago this weekend.

On Friday morning, Donald Trump was credibly accused of having an affair with a second woman who claims she was paid to keep quiet in the run-up to the 2016 election (the first of course was Stormy Daniels). Hours later, Trump and his wife, Melania, both left the White House for Air Force One â but not together.

Trump left the White House at 3:04 p.m. to board a helicopter for Andrews Air Force base, gave reporters a thumbs up, and âseemed to yell something that we couldnât hear over the noise from the helicopter. He ignored questions about Russia and affairs with women,â according to the White House press pool report.

Reporters were asking specifically about a New Yorker report from Friday morning that details an affair between Trump and a Playboy model named Karen McDougal that began in 2006 â the same time Trump was also reportedly courting the porn actress known as Stormy Daniels. Both women have noted in their accounts that Melania had recently given birth to Trumpâs youngest son, Barron, now 11.

(Trump denied the allegations, saying through a spokesperson, âThis is an old story that is just more fake news...The president says he never had a relationship with McDougal," but photographs posted in 2015 show the pair were together at at least two of the events detailed in her story.)

The New Yorker report also details an encounter between Trump and McDougal at his residence in Trump Tower in New York, where McDougal says Trump specifically pointed out Melaniaâs separate bedroom, saying âshe liked her space to read or be alone.â

Melania certainly appeared to want her space or be alone on Friday afternoon, when she departed the White House in a private car without her husband.

"With her schedule, it was easier to meet him on the plane," Melaniaâs communications director, Stephanie Grisham, explained in a statement obtained by CNN.

Itâs not the first time the first lady has traveled separately from her husband in the wake of a damning news report â she also took a separate car to Trumpâs State of the Union address on Jan. 30, in her first public appearance following a Jan. 13 Wall Street Journal report that Trumpâs camp had paid Daniels $130,000 a few weeks before the election, to keep quiet. And in the days after the report was published, Melania cancelled a planned trip to Switzerland with her husband and spent the weekend alone at Mar-a-Lago instead.

Grisham cited "scheduling and logistical issues" that prevented Melania from accompanying her husband on the trip.

If true, it would just be one of many strange coincidences suggesting tension between the couple â including Melaniaâs choice to wear a bright-pink âpussy bowâ Gucci blouse to a debate days after the infamous video of Trump talking about grabbing women âby the pussyâ was leaked. A spokesperson said at the time Melaniaâs outfit was ânot intentional.â

Though the first lady has been largely absent from public appearances, she has been using her social media accounts. In one post, she celebrated the one-year anniversary of Trumpâs inauguration with a photograph of herself standing with a Marine.

âThis has been a year filled with many wonderful moments. Iâve enjoyed the people Iâve been lucky enough to meet throughout our great country & the world!,â she wrote, making no reference to her husband.

The couple marked their 13th wedding anniversary last month.

]]>pam3j8 Gabrielle BluestoneVICE NewsKaren McDougal<![CDATA[Everything we know about the Russian operatives accused of meddling in the U.S. election]]>https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/9kzqpd/everything-we-know-about-the-russian-operatives-accused-of-meddling-in-the-us-electionFri, 16 Feb 2018 21:08:56 +0000Special Counsel Robert Muellerâs latest indictment details Russiaâs complex and wide-ranging campaign to influence the 2016 election, and focuses on 13 individuals, including oligarch Yevgeny Prigozhin, known among Russia media as "Putinâs favorite chef" for hosting many of the presidentâs lavish dinners.

The indictment also focuses on the activities of the infamous St. Petersburg-based Internet Research Agency, which âengaged in operations to interfere with elections and political processes.â Specialists working for the agency, which carried out offensive cyber operations, were instructed to "use any opportunity to criticize Hillary and the rest (except Sanders and Trumpâwe support them)."

The 13 nationals together comprised a sophisticated and well-funded operation that rivals the size of many modern newsrooms. According to the indictment, the Internet Research Agency "was headed by a management group and organized into departments, including: a graphics department; a data analysis department; a search-engine optimization department; an information-technology department to maintain the digital infrastructure used in the operations; and a finance department to budget and allocate funding."

Read: 13 Russian nationals indicted for meddling in U.S. election

Prigozhin is believed to be the mastermind financier behind Russiaâs troll army that spammed social media with fake news, helped organize political demonstrations, and harassed U.S. journalists.

His companies, Concord Management and Consulting, as well as Concord Catering, are believed to have financed the operation, at one point, doling out $1.25 million a month in salaries and bonuses to its operatives, according to Muellerâs findings.

Hereâs what we know about the 13 Russians, who allegedly helped to carry out the Internet Research Agency's âinterference operations targeting the United States.â

Yevgeny Prigozhin

The Russian oligarch, believed to run in Putinâs elusive âinner circle,â and dubbed âthe chefâ is accused of being the chief financial backer of the Internet Research Agency's multi-pronged influence campaign. Starting as early as 2014, the operation allegedly paid for by Prigozhin, sought to attack the U.S. by âimpairing, obstructing, and defeating the lawful functions of government,â according to the indictment.

Underground opposition leader and anti-corruption blogger Alexey Navalny has accused âthe chefâ of benefiting politically and financially from being a member of the Russian presidentâs illusive inner circle.

In this Monday, Sept. 20, 2010 file photo, businessman Yevgeny Prigozhin, left, shows Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, second left, around his factory which produces school means, outside St. Petersburg, Russia. (Alexei Druzhinin, Sputnik, Kremlin Pool Photo via AP, File)

Prigozhin has humble roots. After serving nine years in prison for organized crime related offenses, including fraud and robbery, according to biography published by Meduza, an independent outlet covering Russia, he turned to the restaurant industry, selling hot dogs before eventually breaking into haute cuisine.

Read: Russian opposition leader blasts Instagram for caving to Kremlin censors

In 2001, Putin visited one of Prigozhinâs St. Petersburg restaurants, and where the restaurateur reportedly personally served Putin. From there, the pairâs friendship seemingly blossomed.

âVladimir Putin saw how I built up my business from nothing,â Prigozhin told a St.-Petersburg-based publication, according to Meduza.

Prigozhin is also famously litigious. In 2016, the Russian culinary king filed 20 lawsuits against Google and other internet companies for refusing to remove information about him that appeared on their platforms.

Yet news of the U.S. indictment didnât seem to fluster him Friday. Prigozhin told Russian new agency RIA, that he wasnât at all âbothered.â

Mikhail Ivanovich Bystrov

Bystrovâs ran the show at Internet Research Agency before it shut down operations in December 2016. But his work didnât end with the U.S. elections, apparently. Bystrovâs name appeared again in tax filings for another alleged Russian troll factory: Glavset, which listed the same address â55 Savushkin Street in St. Petersburg â as the defunct Internet Research Agency.

Read: Facebook could tell us a lot about Russia meddling in the 2016 election

Glavset was cited as an âalleged successorâ to the Internet Research Agency in the U.S. Senateâs December report on Russiaâs social media meddling entitled Putinâs Asymmetric Assault on Democracy in Russia and Europe: Implications for US National Security. The report also took aim at Facebook and Twitter for their failure to adequately investigate Russian interference:

â[I]n limiting their investigation to just the Internet Research Agency, Facebook missed that it is only one troll farm which ââhas existed within a larger disinformation ecosystem in St. Petersburg,ââ including Glavset, an alleged successor of the Internet Research Agency, and the Federal News Agency, a reported propaganda ââmedia farm,ââ according to Russian investigative journalists.â

Mikhail Leonidovich Burchik

As executive director, Burchik was allegedly second in command at the Internet Research Agency to Bystrov. Joining the operation in the fall of 2013, Burchik played a pivotal role managing the personnel and planning, according to the indictment.

Aleksandra Yuryevna Krylova

Third in command at Prigozhinâs incredibly well-funded troll factory, Krylova traveled to the U.S. in 2014 under false pretenses to collect information for the then budding operation, according to the indictment.

Anna Vladislavovna Bogacheva

Unlike the defendants outlined above, Bogacheva appears to be less of a manager and more of a data geek. She worked on the operations translations and oversaw data analysis, according to the indictment.

Like Krylova, investigators say she traveled to the U.S. under false pretenses on a fact-finding mission.

Sergey Pavlovich Polozov
